facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 822 of 1963 filed in Supreme Court

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 822 of 1963 Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and decree dated April 7, 1961 of Punjab High Court in Regular First Appeal No. 32 of 1957

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated April, 7, 1961 of the Punjab High Court in Regular First Appeal No. 32 of 1957.

facts.text: Suit brought by plaintiffs-respondents for pre-emption

anchor.surface_text: from the decree of the Punjab High Court in a suit brought by the plaintiffs-respondents for pre-emption.

facts.text: Appellants are vendees to the sale which was preempted

anchor.surface_text: The appellants are vendees to the sale which was preempted. The facts found by the courts below are these.

facts.text: Property in suit consisted of agricultural land as well as some baras in village Jalalpur

anchor.surface_text: The property in suit consisted of agricultural land as well as some baras in village Jalalpur.

facts.text: Punnu Singh and Mansha Singh sold the property in suit on January 15, 1955 to the appellants

anchor.surface_text: Punnu Singh and Mansha Singh who were also parties to the suit as defendants sold the property in suit on January 15,1955 to the appellants.

facts.text: Consolidation proceedings took place in village Jalalpur and came to an end before the suit was filed on January 14, 1956

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter consolidation proceedings took place in this village and came to an end before the present suit was filed on January 14, 1956.

facts.text: Six vendees had no share in the village from before

anchor.surface_text: Of the vendees, six had no share in the village from before while four already had some share in the village.

facts.text: Four vendees had some share in the village from before

anchor.surface_text: Of the vendees, six had no share in the village from before while four already had some share in the village.

facts.text: Six vendees allotted other land in place of the land purchased under the sale-deed as result of consolidation

anchor.surface_text: As a result of the consolidation proceedings, six of the vendees who had no share in the village from before were allotted other land in place of the land which they had purchased under the sale-deed.

facts.text: Four vendees allotted land in two blocks in lieu of land they had before and purchased land

anchor.surface_text: The other four vendees who had some share in the village from before were allotted land in two blocks in lieu of the land they had in the village from before as well as the land which they had purchased by the sale deed in question.

facts.text: Plaintiffs-respondents instituted suit as collaterals and co-sharers seeking pre-emption of land allotted to vendees

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs-respondents instituted the suit on the basis of their being collaterals and co-sharers and wanted that they should be given out of the land allotted to the vendees in consolidation proceedings such land as they would be entitled to after pre-emption of the sale in question.

facts.text: Suit resisted by appellants on ground that not maintainable for land obtained in consolidation

anchor.surface_text: The suit was resisted by the appellants on a number of grounds. The main ground of defence with which we are concerned in the present appeal was whether the suit was maintainable with respect to the land which had been obtained by the vendees during consolidation proceedings in lieu of the land which was the subject matter of the sale deed.

facts.text: Trial court held in favour of plaintiffs and granted decree for pre-emption

anchor.surface_text: The trial court held in favour of the plaintiffs- respondents and granted a decree for pre-emption.

facts.text: High Court on appeal held based on S.24 of the Act that pre-emptor can follow land given in consolidation

anchor.surface_text: On appeal to the High Court by the vendees, the High Court held on the basis of S. 24 of the Patiala and East Punjab States Union Holdings Consolidation and Prevention of Fragmentation Act, No. 5 of 2007 Bk. hereinafter referred to as the Act , that it was open to the pre-emptor to follow the land which had been given to the vendees in consolidation proceedings in lieu of the land which was the subject matter of the sale deed.

facts.text: High Court rejected argument that for four vendees land not distinguishable

anchor.surface_text: Further in the High Court another point was raised on behalf of four of the appellants who had land from before in the village and it was urged that in their case it was not possible to distinguish which land had been allotted to them in place of the land sold and therefore no pre-emption decree should be granted. This argument was also rejected by the High Court, and the appeal was dismissed.

facts.text: High Court refused certificate, appellants obtained special leave from Supreme Court

anchor.surface_text: The High Court having refused the certificate, the appellants applied and obtained ,special leave from this Court and that is how the matter has come before us.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal

anchor.surface_text: The appeal fails and is hereby dismissed.

facts.text: Punnu Singh and Mansha Singh were parties to the suit as defendants

anchor.surface_text: Punnu Singh and Mansha Singh who were also parties to the suit as defendants sold the property

facts.text: Plaintiffs wanted land out of that allotted to vendees equivalent to pre-emption share

anchor.surface_text: wanted that they should be given out of the land allotted to the vendees in consolidation proceedings such land as they would be entitled to after pre-emption of the sale in question.

facts.text: Four appellants raised point in High Court that land not distinguishable for pre-emption

anchor.surface_text: another point was raised on behalf of four of the appellants who had land from before in the village and it was urged that in their case it was not possible to distinguish

facts.text: Supreme Court held construction of S.24 correct by High Court

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of the opinion that the construction of s. 24 by the High Court is correct and the plaintiffs-respondents have a right by virtue of s. 24 of the Act
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated April, 7, 1961 of the Punjab High Court in Regular First Appeal No. 32 of 1957.
the appellants applied and obtained ,special leave from this Court and that is how the matter has come before us.

the High Court held on the basis of S. 24 of the Patiala and East Punjab States Union Holdings Consolidation and Prevention of Fragmentation Act, No. 5 of 2007 Bk. hereinafter referred to as the Act , that it was open to the pre-emptor to follow the land

concepts.interpretation: Preserves the same rights and obligations (including pre-emption disability) in the land allotted under consolidation scheme as attached to the original holding.

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 24, Patiala and East Punjab States Union Holdings Consolidation and Prevention of Fragmentation Act, No. 5 of 2007 Bk.
concepts.unlisted_description: Land-owner or tenant at will has same right in allotted land as in original holding or tenancy.

anchor.surface_text: That section reads as follows- A land-owner or a tenant at will shall have the same right in the land allotted to him in pursuance of the scheme of consolidation as he had in his original holding or tenancy as the case may be.

concepts.interpretation: Implies obligations such as pre-emption liability continue with the allotted land, preventing acquisition of more rights than before.

concepts.unlisted_description: Land-owner or tenant at will has same right in allotted land as in original holding or tenancy.

anchor.surface_text: It is however urged that s. 25 of the Act specifically provides for rights with respect to a lease, mortgage or other encumbrance to attach to the land allotted in place of the original holdings, and that shows that no other rights were intended to survive.

concepts.interpretation: Specific provision for leases, mortgages, encumbrances does not negate general preservation of ownership incidents like pre-emption under s.24.

anchor.surface_text: In Shri Audh Behari Singh v. Gajadhar Jaipuria, 1 this Court held that- The correct legal position seems to be that the law of preemption imposes a limitation or disability upon the ownership of a property to the extent that it restricts the owners unfettered right of sale and compels him to sell the property to his co-sharer or neighbour as the case may be The crux of the whole thing is that the benefit as well as the burden of the right of preemption run with the land

issues.text: whether the suit is maintainable as it is not open to the pre-emptor to follow the land which might have been obtained by the vendees in lieu of the land actually sold to them

anchor.surface_text: 86 5 The main question that has been argued before us is that the suit is not maintainable as it is not open to the pre-emptor to follow the land which might have been obtained by the vendees in lieu of the land actually sold to them. The answer to this question depends upon the interpretation of s. 24 of the Act in the background of the law of pre- emption.

issues.text: whether in the case of four vendees who had land from before it was not possible to distinguish which land had been allotted to them in place of the land sold and therefore no pre-emption decree should be granted

anchor.surface_text: Further in the High Court another point was raised on behalf of four of the appellants who had land from before in the village and it was urged that in their case it was not possible to distinguish which land had been allotted to them in place of the land sold and therefore no pre-emption decree should be granted. This argument was also rejected by the High Court,

issues.text: whether s. 24 only preserves rights and has nothing to do with obligations to which the land may be subject

anchor.surface_text: It is urged that section only preserves the rights and has nothing to do with obligations to which the land may be subject. We are of opinion that this is not so. When the section lays down that the land-owner or a tenant at will shall have the same right in the land allotted to him in pursuance of the scheme of consolidation as he had in his original holding or tenancy, it clearly implies that obligations would also remain the same.

issues.text: whether s. 25 specifically providing for rights with respect to a lease, mortgage or other encumbrance shows that no other rights were intended to survive

anchor.surface_text: It is however urged that s. 25 of the Act specifically provides for rights with respect to a lease, mortgage or other encumbrance to attach to the land allotted in place of the original holdings, and that shows that no other rights were intended to survive. We are of opinion that there is no force in this argument.

issues.text: whether the form of the decree is incorrect

arguments.claim: S.24 gives land-owner same rights and obligations in allotted land as in original holding, including pre-emption liability

anchor.surface_text: That section reads as follows- A land-owner or a tenant at will shall have the same right in the land allotted to him in pursuance of the scheme of consolidation as he had in his original holding or tenancy as the case may be. Clearly the effect of this provision is to give to the land- owner or a tenant at will the same right...

arguments.court_reasoning: Right by virtue of S.24 upheld

holdings.text: the construction of s. 24 by the High Court is correct and the plaintiffs-respondents have a right by virtue of s. 24 of the Act to preempt the land which was allotted to the appellants in lieu of the land which was the subject-matter of the sale-deed

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of the opinion that the construction of s. 24 by the High Court is correct and the plaintiffs-respondents have a right by virtue of s. 24 of the Act

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.24 provides same rights and obligations in allotted land as original; pre-emption disability runs with land per precedents; thus attaches to substituted land

holdings.text: section only preserves the rights and has nothing to do with obligations to which the land may be subject... We are of opinion that this is not so... it clearly implies that obligations would also remain the same

anchor.surface_text: It is urged that section only preserves the rights and has nothing to do with obligations to which the land may be subject. We are of opinion that this is not so. When the section lays down that the land-owner or a tenant at will shall have the same right in the land allotted to him in pursuance of the scheme of consolidation as he had in his original holding or tenancy, it clearly implies that obligations would also remain the same.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Same rights imply same obligations; otherwise vendees acquire more rights e.g. life interest becomes absolute; obligations like limited ownership continue

holdings.text: s. 25 of the Act specifically provides for rights with respect to a lease, mortgage or other encumbrance to attach to the land allotted in place of the original holdings, and that shows that no other rights were intended to survive. We are of opinion that there is no force in this argument

anchor.surface_text: It is however urged that s. 25 of the Act specifically provides for rights with respect to a lease, mortgage or other encumbrance to attach to the land allotted in place of the original holdings, and that shows that no other rights were intended to survive. We are of opinion that there is no force in this argument.

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.25 needed for cross-parcel attachments like leases; pre-emption is ownership incident attaching per s.24, not negated by specific provision

holdings.text: four of the vendees were allotted land in lieu both of what they owned from before and what they got under the sale deed in question. The High Court has held and we think rightly-that there should be no difficulty in finding out how much of the land allotted pertains to the land which was the subject-matter of the sale-deed
holdings.reasoning_summary: Land valued in consolidation proceedings; easy to apportion value equivalent to preempted portion

holdings.text: the form of the decree is incorrect... We have not permitted learned counsel to raise this point for the first time before us, as it was not raised in the High Court. We therefore reject this contention
holdings.reasoning_summary: Point not raised before High Court; cannot be raised first time in Supreme Court

holdings.text: if the original holding of the landowner was subject to the disability of preemption the land allotted in lieu thereof will be equally subject to the same disability

anchor.surface_text: Therefore if the original holding of the landowner was subject to the disability of preemption the land allotted in lieu thereof will be equally subject to the same disability. This will however always be subject to the law of pre- emption itself, and to the well-settled principle of pre- emption, namely, that the preemptor must have a right of preemption at the date of the sale, at the date of the suit and finally at the date of the decree.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pre-emption imposes disability on ownership running with land per Audh Behari Singh; s.24 preserves disabilities

precedents.citation: Shri Audh Behari Singh v. Gajadhar Jaipuria, 1

anchor.surface_text: Shri Audh Behari Singh v. Gajadhar Jaipuria, 1 this Court held that-The correct legal position seems to be that the law of preemption imposes a limitation or disability upon the ownership of a property to the extent that it restricts the owners unfettered right of sale and compels him to sell the property to his cosharer or neighbour as the case may be The crux of the whole thing is that the benefit as well as the burden of the right of preemption run with the land and can be enforced by or against the owner of the land for the time being although the right of the preemptor does number amount to an interest in the land itself The right of preemption is an incident of property and attaches to the land itself

precedents.case_name: Shri Audh Behari Singh v. Gajadhar Jaipuria
precedents.cited_proposition: the law of preemption imposes a limitation or disability upon the ownership of a property to the extent that it restricts the owners unfettered right of sale and compels him to sell the property to his cosharer or neighbour as the case may be The crux of the whole thing is that the benefit as well as the burden of the right of preemption run with the land and can be enforced by or against the owner of the land for the time being although the right of the preemptor does number amount to an interest in the land itself The right of preemption is an incident of property and attaches to the land itself
precedents.cited_holding: The right of preemption is an incident of property and attaches to the land itself

anchor.surface_text: Bishan Singh v. Khazan Singh 2 and pointed out that the right of preemption is number a right to the thing sold but a right to the offer of a thing about to be sold, this being the primary or inherent right, and that the preemptor has a secondary right or a remedial right to follow the thing sold

precedents.cited_proposition: the right of preemption is number a right to the thing sold but a right to the offer of a thing about to be sold, this being the primary or inherent right, and that the preemptor has a secondary right or a remedial right to follow the thing sold

anchor.surface_text: Audh Behari Singhs case 1 assumes importance. In that case it was held that the law of pre- emption imposes a limitation or disability upon the ownership of a property and that the benefit as well as the burden of the right of preemption run with the land

precedents.case_name: Audh Behari Singh v. Gajadhar Jaipuria
precedents.cited_proposition: the law of pre- emption imposes a limitation or disability upon the ownership of a property and that the benefit as well as the burden of the right of preemption run with the land

anchor.surface_text: It is urged that section only preserves the rights and has nothing to do with obligations to which the land may be subject. We are of opinion that this is not so. When the section lays down that the land-owner or a tenant at will shall have the same right in the land allotted to him in pursuance of the scheme of consolidation as he had in his original holding or tenancy, it clearly implies that obligations would also remain the same.
The appeal fails and is hereby dismissed.

edges.explanation: The holding constrains the scope of s.25 to the specific rights (lease, mortgage, encumbrance) that attach to allotted land, enabling a narrower interpretation without rewriting, as the provision admits of such reading given the issue's ambiguity on other rights.

anchor.surface_text: g. liability to preemption which attaches to the land itself and companytinues to attach to the land allotted in lieu of the original holding or tenan

edges.explanation: The holding addresses the issue by interpreting what s.25 specifically provides regarding surviving rights.

anchor.surface_text: It is however urged that s. 25 of the Act specifically provides for rights with respect to a lease, mortgage or other encumbrance to attach to the land allotted in place of the original holdings, and that shows that no other rights were intended to survive. We are of opinion that there is no force in this argument.
The appeal fails and is hereby dismissed.
